str2: A brother, member of the same religious community, especially a fellow-Christian. A brother near or remote.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Neuter Singular
str2: It is permitted, lawful, possible.
Answer, bid, bring word, command. A primary verb; to speak or say.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Accusative 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
From pas and a derivative of rheo; all out-spokenness, i.e. Frankness, bluntness, publicity; by implication, assurance.
Neuter of hostis as conjunction; demonstrative, that; causative, because.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A patriarch, head or founder of a family. From patria and archo; a progenitor.
David, King of Israel. Of Hebrew origin; Dabid, the Israelite king.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To end, finish, die, complete. From a presumed derivative of teleo; to finish life, i.e. Expire.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To bury. A primary verb; to celebrate funeral rites, i.e. Inter.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
A tomb, monument, memorial. From mnaomai; a memorial, i.e. Sepulchral monument.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.
In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 1st Person Plural
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
As far as, up to, until, during. Or achris akh'-rece; akin to akron; until or up to.
This; he, she, it.
A day, the period from sunrise to sunset.
